primary: Traumatic non-compressible torso hemorrhage with hemodynamic instability
patient_selection: Injury below the diaphragm (Zone 1) or pelvis (Zone 3)
Definitive care available within occlusion time limit

absolute: Traumatic aortic injury proximal to balloon position
Injury proximal to Zone 1 (arch or ascending aorta)
relative: Known aortic aneurysm at target zone
Injury with prolonged prehospital time (ischemic burden)

zone_1.location: Descending thoracic aorta (left subclavian to celiac trunk)
zone_1.indication: Abdominal hemorrhage (liver, spleen, major abdominal vessels)
zone_1.ischemic_burden: High - occludes visceral and renal perfusion

zone_2.indication: AVOID - balloon would be unstable, partial occlusion
zone_2.note: Should not deploy balloon in Zone 2

zone_3.ischemic_burden: Lower - preserves visceral and renal perfusion

technique.confirmation: Fluoroscopy if available, otherwise external landmarks
technique.inflation: Slow inflation with saline, observe BP response
technique.monitoring: Continuous BP, assess for balloon migration

distal: Potential for reperfusion injury upon deflation

outcomes.hemodynamic_effect: Immediate increase in proximal BP in 80-90% of patients
outcomes.survival: Bridge to repair - survival depends on definitive treatment success
outcomes.ischemic_complications: Proportional to occlusion time and zone

prefLabel.@value: REBOA - Resuscitative Endovascular Balloon Occlusion of Aorta

definition.@value: Endovascular technique for temporary aortic occlusion using a balloon catheter to reduce distal hemorrhage and augment central perfusion as a bridge to definitive hemorrhage control

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Define the zones of aortic occlusion and their indications
Describe the technique of REBOA insertion
Understand the physiologic effects of aortic occlusion
Recognize the time constraints and complications of REBOA
Apply REBOA as a bridge to definitive hemorrhage control
clinical_pearls: REBOA is a BRIDGE to definitive care, not definitive treatment
Zone 1 = abdominal hemorrhage; Zone 3 = pelvic hemorrhage; Zone 2 = avoid
Zone 1 occlusion causes visceral and renal ischemia - limit to 60-90 minutes
Zone 3 preserves renal and visceral perfusion - longer tolerance
Prepare for reperfusion syndrome (hyperkalemia, acidosis) upon deflation
External landmarks: umbilicus = L4, xiphoid = T10

medicalCode.description: Endovascular repair of iliac artery with temporary aortic balloon occlusion
